*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.raw_text: *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (abolishing distinction between invitees and licensees and recognizing unified duty of reasonable care)
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of premises owes a duty to all lawful entrants and users of adjacent public ways, including pedestrians on public sidewalks, to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to prevent foreseeable harm caused by conditions on the property that present an unreasonable risk of injury.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard squarely abolished the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopted a unified duty of reasonable care owed by property owners/occupiers to all lawful entrants. The full opinion (not just this concurrence) makes clear that the occupier must exercise reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and prevent foreseeable harm, and Mounsey has been cited as extending that duty to lawful users of adjacent public ways affected by conditions on the property. The provided excerpt is only a concurrence focusing on trespassers, so it indirectly, rather than expressly, supports the broader proposition, hence medium confidence.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)).

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.raw_text: *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995) (duty extends to preventing foreseeable harm to persons on adjacent ways)
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of premises owes a duty to all lawful entrants and users of adjacent public ways, including pedestrians on public sidewalks, to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to prevent foreseeable harm caused by conditions on the property that present an unreasonable risk of injury.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly limits a landowner’s duty with respect to adjacent public highways and rejects an expanded duty to provide safe passage across such ways. While the court reiterates the general rule that a landowner must use its land with reasonable care so as not to injure travelers on adjacent highways, it holds that this does not extend to a duty to make or seek alterations to a public way and emphasizes that landowners are “typically not held to any duty with respect to public highways” beyond avoiding creating hazards. Thus, it does not support the broad proposition that owners owe a duty to all lawful entrants and sidewalk pedestrians to prevent all foreseeable harms caused by conditions on the property that present an unreasonable risk, as applied here to control or modify an adjacent public way.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. at.raw_text: *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. at 743–44 (duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm from conditions on land)
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. at.proposition: This duty extends to artificial and natural conditions on the land, including trees and overhanging limbs that pose a foreseeable risk of falling onto public sidewalks and injuring pedestrians.

*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.raw_text: *Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196, 198–99 (1994) (duty of reasonable care in maintaining premises, including conditions abutting public ways)
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.proposition: This duty extends to artificial and natural conditions on the land, including trees and overhanging limbs that pose a foreseeable risk of falling onto public sidewalks and injuring pedestrians.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a commercial landlord’s duty to protect lawful occupants from reasonably foreseeable criminal acts in common areas, not with a landowner’s duty concerning physical conditions on land abutting public ways. It does not discuss natural or artificial conditions such as trees or overhanging limbs, nor any duty relating to hazards falling onto public sidewalks. Using this case to support the specific proposition about trees and overhanging limbs would therefore be inaccurate.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 360 (1965)… The question in this appeal is whether the evidence warranted a finding that an attack on the plaintiff was reasonably foreseeable.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006) (duty where risk of harm is foreseeable and reasonable person would act to prevent it)
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Defendant further had a duty to use reasonable care to prevent an unreasonable risk of harm arising from a condition on his land when he knew or reasonably should have known that such condition posed a foreseeable risk of injury to persons lawfully using the adjacent public sidewalk.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses a landowner’s duty based on foreseeability and the storage of dangerous instrumentalities (firearms) on residential premises, but it does not concern or discuss conditions on land creating risks to persons using an adjacent public sidewalk. The duty recognized in Jupin is to ensure proper storage of guns in a home where a violent, mentally unstable person has unsupervised access, not a duty regarding conditions abutting a public way or sidewalk users. Thus, it does not support the specific sidewalk-related duty articulated in the proposition.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e hold that a homeowner who permits a guest to keep guns permanently on her premises and allows a third person with a criminal history and mental difficulties unsupervised access to the property, has a duty to ensure that the firearms are properly and safely stored. … [A] defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.” (447 Mass. at 147-48, 155.)

*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 730\u2.raw_text: *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 730–32 (2000) (question of negligence based on foreseeability of harm under particular weather conditions)
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 730\u2.proposition: Defendant further had a duty to use reasonable care to prevent an unreasonable risk of harm arising from a condition on his land when he knew or reasonably should have known that such condition posed a foreseeable risk of injury to persons lawfully using the adjacent public sidewalk.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 730\u2.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landowner’s duty regarding dangerous conditions on land that create a foreseeable risk of harm to persons lawfully using an adjacent public sidewalk. Luoni v. Berube addresses a homeowner’s duty (or lack thereof) to protect a social guest from injuries caused by fireworks brought and set off by other guests on the property, and it explicitly rejects expanding landowner duty to cover such third-party acts absent a special relationship or the landowner’s creation/control of the danger. It neither involves adjacent public sidewalks nor recognizes the broader duty described in the proposition; if anything, it cuts against such an expansive duty theory.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 730\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The duty of a landowner under general principles of common-law negligence governing dangerous conditions on his land is established. ‘A landowner must act as a reasonable [person] in maintaining . . . property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The obligation to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition refers to preexisting physical conditions…. There is no room in this branch of tort law for the plaintiff’s contention that the fireworks somehow constituted a physical condition on the defendants’ land….”

*Flood v. Southland Corp.*, 416 Mass. 62.raw_text: *Flood v. Southland Corp.*, 416 Mass. 62, 71 (1993) (foreseeability of harm is central to negligence analysis)
*Flood v. Southland Corp.*, 416 Mass. 62.proposition: Defendant’s liability is not negated by the fact that the limb fell during a storm because the risk that a cracked and drooping limb would fall under typical Massachusetts summer storm conditions was plainly foreseeable and, indeed, was specifically brought to Defendant’s attention.
*Flood v. Southland Corp.*, 416 Mass. 62.support_reasoning: The case is about a stabbing at a convenience store and addresses foreseeability of criminal acts by third parties in a premises-liability context, not falling limbs, storms, or natural conditions. While the opinion confirms that reasonable foreseeability of harm is central to negligence and that a defendant cannot avoid duty merely because the precise manner of injury was not predictable, it does not discuss or hold that liability is unaffected by the fact that an event occurred during a storm or under typical weather conditions. Thus it cannot be cited as direct authority for the specific storm/limb foreseeability proposition, though it is consistent with the general foreseeability principle underlying that argument.
*Flood v. Southland Corp.*, 416 Mass. 62.relevant_excerpt: “Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff…to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional… Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant…. In deciding on the reasonable foreseeability of harm, all the circumstances are examined…. A jury would be warranted in such circumstances in determining that a risk of harm, the stabbing of someone, was reasonably foreseeable.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640–41 (1996) (liability where defendant fails to take reasonable measures to address known or foreseeable risks from natural conditions)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The presence of wind and rain on August 15, 2023, does not constitute an unforeseeable “Act of God” relieving Defendant of liability because the weather was within the range of conditions reasonably anticipated in the area, and Defendant’s prior negligence in failing to address the defective limb was a substantial factor in causing the limb to fall.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on causation and foreseeability in the context of keys left in ignitions, not on liability for natural conditions, weather, or an Act of God defense. It explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence, which runs counter to the user’s proposition that the weather-related harm was foreseeable and did not relieve the defendant of liability. Nothing in this text addresses wind, rain, tree limbs, or the Act of God doctrine.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973) (notice may be actual or constructive where condition exists for sufficient time and is readily observable)
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.proposition: Defendant had both actual and constructive notice of the dangerous condition of the limb. Neighbors specifically alerted Defendant to the cracked, drooping limb and suggested he consult an arborist, and the condition was observable and would have been discovered upon reasonable inspection.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with premises liability for a foreign substance on a stairway and whether the defendant had actual or constructive notice based on how long the substance had been present and the opportunity for discovery. It does not involve trees, limbs, or third-party warnings, nor does it discuss a situation where neighbors specifically alerted the defendant to a dangerous condition. While it generally recognizes constructive notice where a condition exists long enough to be discovered upon reasonable inspection, it does not address or illustrate actual notice like that described in the proposition, so it only tangentially and incompletely supports the stated proposition.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.raw_text: *Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362, 365 (1980) (pain and suffering as element of damages)
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.proposition: Plaintiff has also sustained and will continue to sustain non‑economic damages, including physical pain and suffering, mental anguish, emotional distress, inconvenience, and loss of enjoyment of life, all proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses that the plaintiff’s damages included "enormous pain and suffering" that would persist throughout her life, recognizing pain and suffering as a compensable element of damages. While the case does not enumerate all of the specific non‑economic categories listed in the proposition (mental anguish, emotional distress, inconvenience, loss of enjoyment of life), it clearly affirms the availability of non‑economic damages for pain and suffering and related permanent impairments due to the defendant’s negligence. Thus it supports the general point that such non‑economic harms are recoverable, though it is not authority for each listed subcategory by name.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the judge did not abuse his discretion. There was evidence to support a finding that there would be substantial loss of earning capacity in the future. More important, there was evidence of enormous pain and suffering, which will persist over the plaintiff’s estimated remaining life span of some forty-three years, compounded by permanent loss of bodily functions and massive scarring and disfigurement.

*McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.raw_text: *McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.*, 408 Mass. 704, 717 (1990) (measure of damages is to place plaintiff as nearly as possible in position she would have been in absent tort)
*McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including past and future pain and suffering, past and future medical expenses, past and future loss of earning capacity, and any other compensable losses under Massachusetts law.
*McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.case_name: McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.
*McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with fraud, Chapter 93A, and prejudgment interest in a commercial dispute between businesses. It does not address tort personal injury damages, nor does it discuss components such as pain and suffering, medical expenses, or loss of earning capacity. While it briefly mentions that prejudgment interest is to compensate for loss of use of money, it does not articulate the broad Massachusetts tort damages rule stated in the proposition, so it is not proper authority for that proposition.
*McEvoy Travel Bureau, Inc. v. Norton Co.relevant_excerpt: “The purpose of prejudgment interest under G. L. c. 231, § 6B, is ‘to compensate a damaged party for the loss of use or the unlawful detention of money.’ … The damaged party is entitled to a return on the money that the party would have had but for the other party’s wrongdoing. To give the damaged party more than that would go beyond the purpose of the statute. The purpose behind the prejudgment interest statute is not to penalize the wrongdoer … or to make the damaged party more than whole.”

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds the jurisdictional minimum for the Superior Court and involves a claim for personal injuries sounding in negligence.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose in Berkshire County, the Property is located in Berkshire County, and Defendant resides in Berkshire County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, Plaintiff’s recovery is not barred unless her negligence, if any, was greater than the total negligence attributable to Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover these expenses under Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on personal injury damages).

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff also seeks costs of this action as provided by G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.
